content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a human player, I would choose a strategy that maximizes my total earnings over the 75 rounds. Since the payoff structures favor choosing the opposite of the opponent when I pick R and the same when I pick B, it seems like a dominant strategy to always pick B in this case, because regardless of what the anonymous player chooses, I end up with a higher payout (40$ vs 35$). However, since we don't know the opponent's strategy, I can only assume that they will also choose B, which would lead to me earning 40$ in each round. So, my choice is {B}.

That being said, it is important to note that this assumption about the opponent's choice might not always be correct. If the opponent was aware of my strategy and decided to exploit it by consistently choosing R, they could potentially earn 35$ in each round while I only get 40$. In a real-world setting, it would be wise to observe the opponent's choices for a few rounds before deciding on a consistent strategy. But since this is a one-time simulation without the ability to adapt during play, I will stick with my initial choice of {B}.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 40$. Your opponent's payoff is 40$. Please play the next round.

In this specific scenario, where both me (B) and my anonymous opponent also choose B in the first round, we each earn 40$ as a result. For the next round, I would stick with my original strategy of choosing B since it was profitable in the previous round. So, for the second round, I will choose {B} again.

It's important to emphasize that this choice is based on the assumption that the opponent's behavior does not change and they continue to pick B as well. However, in a real-world setting with adaptive opponents, it would be essential to keep an eye on the opponent's strategy and make adjustments accordingly to maximize payoffs over multiple rounds.
